post.title: Training Your Own LLM using privateGPT

paragraphs.name: c634
paragraphs.text: Training Your Own LLM using privateGPT

paragraphs.name: 7cfe
paragraphs.text: Learn how to train your own language model without exposing your private data to the provider

paragraphs.name: 352a
paragraphs.text: Photo by Richard Bell on Unsplash

One of the major concerns of using public AI services such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT is the risk of exposing your private data to the provider. For commercial use, this remains the biggest concerns for companies considering adopting AI technologies.

paragraphs.name: 4b02
paragraphs.text: Many times, you want to create your own language model that are trained on your set of data (such as sales insights, customers feedback, etc), but at the same time you do not want to expose all these sensitive data to a AI provider such as OpenAI. So the ideal way is to train your own LLM locally, without needing to upload your data to the cloud.

paragraphs.name: d132
paragraphs.text: If your data is public and you don’t mind exposing them to ChatGPT, I have another article that shows how you can connect ChatGPT with your own data:

paragraphs.name: c872
paragraphs.text:
Connecting ChatGPT with Your Own Data using LlamaIndex
Learn how to create your own chatbot for your businesslevelup.gitconnected.com

paragraphs.name: 2b8a
paragraphs.text: In this article, I will show you how you can use an open-source project called privateGPT to utilize an LLM so that it can answer questions (like ChatGPT) based on your custom training data, all without sacrificing the privacy of your data.

paragraphs.name: e4bf
paragraphs.text: It is important to note that privateGPT is currently a proof-of-concept and is not production ready.

paragraphs.name: d408
paragraphs.text: Downloading privateGPT
To try out privateGPT, you can go to GitHub using the following link: https://github.com/imartinez/privateGPT.

paragraphs.name: 43ea
paragraphs.text: You can either download the repository by clicking on the Code | Download ZIP button:

paragraphs.name: 37bf
paragraphs.text: Or, if you have git installed on your system, use the following command in Terminal to clone the repository:

paragraphs.name: 062d
paragraphs.text: $ git clone https://github.com/imartinez/privateGPT

paragraphs.name: 232d
paragraphs.text: Either case, once the repository is downloaded onto your computer, the privateGPT directory should have the following files and folder:

paragraphs.name: 9e09
paragraphs.text: Installing the Required Python Packages

paragraphs.name: 9e9e
paragraphs.text: privateGPT uses a number of Python packages. They are encapsulated in the requirements.txt file:

paragraphs.name: a035
paragraphs.text:
langchain==0.0.171
pygpt4all==1.1.0
chromadb==0.3.23
llama-cpp-python==0.1.50
urllib3==2.0.2
pdfminer.six==20221105
python-dotenv==1.0.0
unstructured==0.6.6
extract-msg==0.41.1
tabulate==0.9.0
pandoc==2.3
pypandoc==1.11

paragraphs.name: 248c
paragraphs.text: The easiest way to install them is to use pip:

paragraphs.name: 5b96
paragraphs.text:
$ cd privateGPT
$ pip install -r requirements.txt

From my experimentation, some required Python packages may not be installed when you perform the installation above. You will know this later on when you try to run either the ingest.py or privateGPT.py file. In such instances, simply install the missing package individually.

paragraphs.name: a2c1
paragraphs.text: Editing the Environment file

paragraphs.name: 1e12
paragraphs.text: The example.env file contains several settings used by privateGPT. Here is its content:

paragraphs.name: bc04
paragraphs.text:
PERSIST_DIRECTORY=db
MODEL_TYPE=GPT4All
MODEL_PATH=models/ggml-gpt4all-j-v1.3-groovy.bin
EMBEDDINGS_MODEL_NAME=all-MiniLM-L6-v2
MODEL_N_CTX=1000

paragraphs.name: 207e
paragraphs.text: PERSIST_DIRECTORY — the directory that will hold the local vector store after your documents are loaded and processed

paragraphs.name: bd5d
paragraphs.text: MODEL_TYPE — the type of model you are using. Here, it is set to GPT4All (a free open-source alternative to ChatGPT by OpenAI).

paragraphs.name: ed03
paragraphs.text: MODEL_PATH — the path where the LLM is located. Here it is set to the models directory and the model used is ggml-gpt4all-j-v1.3-groovy.bin (you will learn where to download this model in the next section)

paragraphs.name: 1afb
paragraphs.text: EMBEDDINGS_MODEL_NAME — this refers to the name of a transformer model. Here it is set to all-MiniLM-L6-v2, which maps sentences & paragraphs to a 384 dimensional dense vector space and can be used for tasks like clustering or semantic search.

paragraphs.name: 046b
paragraphs.text: MODEL_N_CTX — Maximum token limit for both embeddings and LLM models
Rename the example.env to .env.

paragraphs.name: 5ab7
paragraphs.text: Once this is done, the .env file will become a hidden file.

paragraphs.name: e1f7
paragraphs.text: Downloading the Model
In order for privateGPT to work, it needs to pre-trained model (a LLM). As privateGPT is using GPT4All, you can download the LLMs from: https://gpt4all.io/index.html:

paragraphs.name: 158c
paragraphs.text: Since the default environment file specifies the ggml-gpt4all-j-v1.3-groovy.bin LLM, download the first model and then create a new folder named models inside the privateGPT folder. Put the ggml-gpt4all-j-v1.3-groovy.bin file inside the models folder:
Preparing Your Data

paragraphs.name: 2b4e
paragraphs.text: If you look into the ingest.py file, you will notice the following code snippet:

paragraphs.name: c704
paragraphs.text:
".csv": (CSVLoader, {}),
    # ".docx": (Docx2txtLoader, {}),
    ".doc": (UnstructuredWordDocumentLoader, {}),
    ".docx": (UnstructuredWordDocumentLoader, {}),
    ".enex": (EverNoteLoader, {}),
    ".eml": (UnstructuredEmailLoader, {}),
    ".epub": (UnstructuredEPubLoader, {}),
    ".html": (UnstructuredHTMLLoader, {}),
    ".md": (UnstructuredMarkdownLoader, {}),
    ".odt": (UnstructuredODTLoader, {}),
    ".pdf": (PDFMinerLoader, {}),
    ".ppt": (UnstructuredPowerPointLoader, {}),
    ".pptx": (UnstructuredPowerPointLoader, {}),
    ".txt": (TextLoader, {"encoding": "utf8"}),

paragraphs.name: 3b98
paragraphs.text: This means privateGPT is able to support the following document types:

paragraphs.name: bbe5
paragraphs.text: .csv: CSV

paragraphs.name: 5dc4
paragraphs.text: .doc: Word Document

paragraphs.name: 1b3e
paragraphs.text: .docx: Word Document

paragraphs.name: 9df7
paragraphs.text: .enex: EverNote

paragraphs.name: 21df
paragraphs.text: .eml: Email
.epub: EPub

paragraphs.name: 47fc
paragraphs.text: .html: HTML File

paragraphs.name: fa8b
paragraphs.text: .md: Markdown

paragraphs.name: 54ef
paragraphs.text: .odt: Open Document Text

paragraphs.name: 8b7a
paragraphs.text: .pdf: Portable Document Format (PDF)

paragraphs.name: 59e9
paragraphs.text: .ppt : PowerPoint Document

paragraphs.name: ef78
paragraphs.text: .pptx : PowerPoint Document

paragraphs.name: ad2b
paragraphs.text: .txt: Text file (UTF-8)

paragraphs.name: 70de
paragraphs.text: Each type of document is specified with the respective document loader. For example, you use the UnstructuredWordDocumentLoader class to load .doc and .docx Word documents.

paragraphs.name: fc32
paragraphs.text: By default, privateGPT comes with the state_of_the_union.txt file located in the source_documents folder. I am going to delete it and replace it with a document named Singapore.pdf.

paragraphs.name: 757e
paragraphs.text: This document was created from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore. You can download any page from Wikipedia as a PDF document by clicking Tools | Download as PDF:

paragraphs.name: 8b78
paragraphs.text: You can put any documents that are supported by privateGPT into the source_documents folder. For my example, I only put one document.

paragraphs.name: 84e8
paragraphs.text: Creating the Embeddings for Your Documents

paragraphs.name: 00a5
paragraphs.text: Once your document(s) are in place, you are ready to create embeddings for your documents.

paragraphs.name: 4ada
paragraphs.text: Creating embeddings refers to the process of generating vector representations for words, sentences, or other units of text. These vector representations capture semantic and syntactic information about the text, allowing machines to understand and process natural language more effectively.

paragraphs.name: cb51
paragraphs.text: Type the following in Terminal (the ingest.py file is provided in the privateGPT folder):

paragraphs.name: 194a
paragraphs.text: $ python ingest.py

paragraphs.name: fbb1
paragraphs.text: Depending on the machine you are using and the number of documents you put in the source_documents folder, the embedding processing may take quite a while to complete.

paragraphs.name: ca70
paragraphs.text: When it is done, you will see something like this:

paragraphs.name: a572
paragraphs.text:
Loading documents from source_documents
Loaded 1 documents from source_documents
Split into 692 chunks of text (max. 500 characters each)
Using embedded DuckDB with persistence: data will be stored in: db

paragraphs.name: e1ec
paragraphs.text: The embeddings are saved in the db folder, in the form of Chroma DB:

paragraphs.name: b758
paragraphs.text: Chroma is the open-source embedding database.

paragraphs.name: 88ff
paragraphs.text: Asking Questions

paragraphs.name: bb50
paragraphs.text: You are now ready to ask questions! Type the following command in Terminal:

paragraphs.name: 407f
paragraphs.text: $ python privateGPT.py
It will take a while for the model to be loaded. In the process you will see the following:

paragraphs.name: 8ff1
paragraphs.text:
Using embedded DuckDB with persistence: data will be stored in: db
gptj_model_load: loading model from 'models/ggml-gpt4all-j-v1.3-groovy.bin' - please wait ...
gptj_model_load: n_vocab = 50400
gptj_model_load: n_ctx   = 2048
gptj_model_load: n_embd  = 4096
gptj_model_load: n_head  = 16
gptj_model_load: n_layer = 28
gptj_model_load: n_rot   = 64
gptj_model_load: f16     = 2
gptj_model_load: ggml ctx size = 4505.45 MB
gptj_model_load: memory_size =   896.00 MB, n_mem = 57344
gptj_model_load: ................................... done
gptj_model_load: model size =  3609.38 MB / num tensors = 285

Enter a query:

paragraphs.name: 42a3
paragraphs.text: At the prompt, you can type in your question. I asked: “What is the population in Singapore?”. It took privateGPT quite a while to come up with the answer. Once it managed to find an answer, it give you the answer and cited the source for the answer:

paragraphs.name: 5bb3
paragraphs.text: You can continue to ask a follow-up question:

paragraphs.name: fc1e
paragraphs.text: If you like reading my articles and that it helped your career/study, please consider signing up as a Medium member. It is $5 a month, and it gives you unlimited access to all the articles (including mine) on Medium. If you sign up using the following link, I will earn a small commission (at no additional cost to you). Your support means that I will be able to devote more time on writing articles like this.

paragraphs.name: 5ef0
paragraphs.text:
Join Medium with my referral link - Wei-Meng Lee
Read every story from Wei-Meng Lee (and thousands of other writers on Medium). Your membership fee directly supports…weimenglee.medium.com

paragraphs.name: e370
paragraphs.text: Summary

paragraphs.name: 64ef
paragraphs.text: While privateGPT is a currently a proof-of-concept, it looks promising, However, it is not ready for production. There are a couple of issues:

paragraphs.name: a0f5
paragraphs.text: Slow inferencing. It took a while to perform the text embedding, but this is acceptable as this is a one-time process. However, inferencing is slow, especially on slower machines. I used a M1 Mac with 32GB ram and it still took a while to churn out the answer.

paragraphs.name: bc1b
paragraphs.text: Memory hog. privateGPT uses lots of memory, and after asking one or two questions, I will get an out-of-memory error, like this:

paragraphs.name: 5beb
paragraphs.text: segmentation fault python privateGPT.py. /Users/weimenglee/miniforge3/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/resource_tracker.py:224: UserWarning: resource_tracker: There appear to be 1 leaked semaphore objects to clean up at shutdown. warnings.warn(‘resource_tracker: There appear to be %d ‘

paragraphs.name: a433
paragraphs.text: Until the author of privateGPT fixes the above two issues, privateGPT remains an experiment to see how you can train your LLM without exposing your private data to the cloud.

paragraphs.name: 1c74
paragraphs.text: Level Up Coding

paragraphs.name: f85c
paragraphs.text: Thanks for being a part of our community! Before you go:
